comment.author: 26598199@N00
comment._content: I love all these pictures. But I just wanted to represent for my profession. Line Service baby! In history forever.

comment.author: 22915586@N03
comment._content: These are B-25's NOT A-20 Havocs.  Easy to spot difference is the tail assembly.  B-25 has a twin tail. A-20 had a single tail.  Note:  The A-20 also had the nickname: Widow Maker

comment.author: 29447297@N00
comment._content: "Widow Maker" was a nickname for the Martin B-26 Marauder: www.flickr.com/photos/hawk914/533638778/ When introduced the B-26 had a comparatively high accident rate. Those who flew it noted that early models had a problem with runaway propellers (constant speed props failing to flat pitch at takeoff): www.b26.com/page/shop_talk.htm

comment.author: 22968943@N05
comment._content: I suspect there have been several aircraft called "widow maker" over the years :)  Thankfully, my father survived the A-20 quite well :)  I do think that the term Widow Maker might have been applied to the night fighter version of the A-20, or perhaps its successor.  One was IIRC the P-60, the other the P-71 and I can never remember which was which.

comment.author: 16612979@N00
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called North American B-25 Mitchells, and we'd love to have your photo added to the group. These are B-25C on the North American Company line.

comment.author: 39527539@N00
comment._content: What a great photo!  My grandfather was a turret gunner in one during the war.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Thanks for all the input. The catalog record reflects the original OWI agency caption, but yes indeed, this is a B-25. We will consider further corrections to the record.

comment.author: 34162648@N08
comment._content: Wow, I enjoy this pic of the B-25's. For myself  I love the "J" models.

comment.author: 44486929@N00
comment._content:
I agree with Mitch. I think the name may have been used for many a/c but if some body mentions it, I automatically think of the Martin B-26 Marauder.

"One a day in Tampa Bay"!

comment.author: 52973624@N05
comment._content: This is a fantastic photo, beautifully captured

comment.author: 76084118@N06
comment._content: I'm confused. The A20 and B25 were very different airplanes. This is definitely a photo of a B25.

comment.author: 45229040@N02
comment._content: The B-25 Mitchell Bomber to me was the best looking of all the WWII multi engine aircraft, in addition to being the first aircraft to let the Japanese know America could reach out and touch you.....
